Comment: * [Bernie Sanders will be in Philly on May Day for a rally with AFL-CIO](https://www.inquirer.com/politics/nation/bernie-sanders-fighting-oligarchy-philly-harrisburg-bethlehem-pennsylvaina-20250428.html)  * [‘These Republicans cannot know a moment of peace’: Pritzker calls for mass protests against GOP](https://www.msnbc.com/inside-with-jen-psaki/watch/-these-republicans-cannot-know-a-moment-of-peace-pritzker-calls-for-mass-protests-against-gop-238512709833)  This strike, while focused on LA County workers and their goal of securing a better contract, is also a spark. Sparks like these could be what ignites a national general strike against the current Admin. And this is with 55,000 people. If they can get a contract favorable to them, then what could millions do...

Comment: > Sparks like these could be what ignites a national general strike against the current Admin.  The only downside to a strike is not enough people striking.
Author: tech57

Comment: I don't understand why this mythology of a general strike so popular on Reddit.    Countries that have general strikes are ones that have a high level of unionization because it's the unions that organize the strikes and have a strike fund to take care of people who live hand to mouth and can't afford to go for a week or more without working.   Those conditions do not exist in the United States so expecting a general strike here is like expecting a ski industry in Florida. The conditions don't exist for one.
Author: Independent-Roof-774

Comment: A general strike is never going to happen in America for at minimum 20 years. The organization doesn't exist. The unionization doesn't exist. The political engagement doesn't exist. The leadership doesn't exist.
Author: DisMFer

Comment: The level of unionization in the US is too low to have much more of this. Also some of the major unions, like the UAW have come out **in favor** of Trump's tariffs.
Author: Independent-Roof-774

Comment: [The '3.5% rule': How a small minority can change the world](https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20190513-it-only-takes-35-of-people-to-change-the-world)  >Looking at hundreds of campaigns over the last century, Chenoweth found that nonviolent campaigns are twice as likely to achieve their goals as violent campaigns. And although the exact dynamics will depend on many factors, she has shown it takes around 3.5% of the population actively participating in the protests to ensure serious political change.  As many people as possible would be ideal, but sometimes you just need *enough*.
Author: brain_overclocked

Comment: Protesting is like working out a muscle: the more you do it, the stronger it gets. But if you don't work it out regularly, well, it begins to atrophy.
Author: brain_overclocked

Comment: And we've already hit 1% with some of the coordinated protests downplayed by the media.
Author: Grandpa_No

Comment: I've been in six protests against Trump so far. And 80% of the people at these protests have been boomers.   I've had several arguments in the last few days here on Reddit Politics with non-boomers who made all kinds of excuses why they can't participate in the protests.
Author: Independent-Roof-774

Comment: 30% of my senior exercise class showed at the last one. People in their 70s and 80s. I print the flyers and pass them out. Some seniors don't have internet or are not on social media. Getting ready for Mayday.  My husband was an SEIU member.
Author: TrinkieTrinkie522cat
